title: HTML & CSS: Build Your First Website
excerpt: Step-by-step guide to creating your first webpage. No prior web development knowledge required.
content:
HTML & CSS: Build Your First Website

Welcome to web development! In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create your first webpage using HTML and CSS. No prior experience needed!

What are HTML and CSS?

HTML (HyperText Markup Language)

HTML is the skeleton of every webpage. It defines the structure and content:

  • Headings - Titles and section headers
  • Paragraphs - Blocks of text
  • Images - Pictures and graphics
  • Links - Clickable connections to other pages
  • Lists - Ordered and unordered items

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)

CSS is the styling that makes websites look beautiful:

  • Colors - Text and background colors
  • Fonts - Text styles and sizes
  • Layout - Positioning of elements
  • Spacing - Margins and padding
  • Responsive Design - Making sites work on all devices

Setting Up Your Workspace

You don't need any special software to start! All you need is:

  1. A text editor (VS Code, Notepad, or any text editor)
  2. A web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge)

I recommend VS Code because it's free and has great features for web development.

Your First HTML Page

Create a new file called index.html and add this basic structure:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>My First Website</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Welcome to My Website!</h1>
    <p>This is my first webpage. I'm learning HTML!</p>
</body>
</html>

What Each Tag Does:

  • <!DOCTYPE html> - Tells the browser this is HTML5
  • <html> - The root element of the page
  • <head> - Contains meta information
  • <title> - The text shown in the browser tab
  • <body> - Where all visible content goes
  • <h1> - Main heading (largest)
  • <p> - Paragraph of text

Common HTML Elements

Headings

<h1>Main Heading</h1>
<h2>Subheading</h2>
<h3>Smaller Heading</h3>
<h4>Even Smaller</h4>
<h5>Small</h5>
<h6>Smallest</h6>

Text Formatting

<p>This is a paragraph.</p>
<strong>This text is bold</strong>
<em>This text is italic</em>
<br>  <!-- Line break -->
<hr>  <!-- Horizontal rule -->

Lists

<!-- Unordered List (bullets) -->
<ul>
    <li>First item</li>
    <li>Second item</li>
    <li>Third item</li>
</ul>

<!-- Ordered List (numbers) -->
<ol>
    <li>Step one</li>
    <li>Step two</li>
    <li>Step three</li>
</ol>

Links and Images

<!-- Link to another website -->
<a href="https://www.example.com">Visit Example.com</a>

<!-- Link to another page -->
<a href="about.html">About Me</a>

<!-- Image -->
<img src="image.jpg" alt="Description of image">

Adding CSS Styling

Create a new file called style.css and link it to your HTML:

<!-- In the <head> section -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">

Now add some basic styling to your CSS file:

/* style.css */
body {
    font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
    line-height: 1.6;
    margin: 0;
    padding: 20px;
    background-color: #f4f4f4;
}

h1 {
    color: #333;
    text-align: center;
}

p {
    color: #666;
    font-size: 18px;
}

/* Style links */
a {
    color: #007bff;
    text-decoration: none;
}

a:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
}

CSS Selectors and Properties

Basic Selectors

/* Element selector */
p { color: blue; }

/* Class selector (use class="highlight" in HTML) */
.highlight { background-color: yellow; }

/* ID selector (use id="main-title" in HTML) */
#main-title { font-size: 2em; }

Common CSS Properties

.box {
    color: red;              /* Text color */
    background-color: blue;  /* Background color */
    font-size: 16px;        /* Text size */
    font-weight: bold;      /* Text weight */
    margin: 10px;           /* Space outside */
    padding: 15px;          /* Space inside */
    border: 1px solid black;/* Border */
    width: 200px;           /* Width */
    height: 100px;          /* Height */
}

Building a Simple Portfolio Page

Let's create a complete portfolio page together:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>My Portfolio</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>
<body>
    <header>
        <h1>John Doe</h1>
        <p>Aspiring Web Developer</p>
    </header>
    
    <section id="about">
        <h2>About Me</h2>
        <p>I'm learning web development and loving every minute of it!</p>
    </section>
    
    <section id="skills">
        <h2>My Skills</h2>
        <ul>
            <li>HTML</li>
            <li>CSS</li>
            <li>JavaScript (learning)</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    
    <footer>
        <p>Contact me: john@example.com</p>
    </footer>
</body>
</html>

Making Your Site Responsive

Add this to your CSS to make your site work on mobile devices:

/* Responsive design */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
    body {
        padding: 10px;
        font-size: 14px;
    }
    
    h1 {
        font-size: 24px;
    }
}

Common Mistakes to Avoid

  1. Forgetting to close tags - Every opening tag needs a closing tag
  2. Using inline styles - Keep CSS separate from HTML
  3. Not using semantic HTML - Use <header>, <nav>, <section> instead of just <div>
  4. Ignoring accessibility - Always add alt text to images
  5. Not testing on mobile - Always check how your site looks on phones

Next Steps in Web Development

After mastering HTML and CSS, here's what to learn next:

  • JavaScript - Make your websites interactive
  • CSS Frameworks - Bootstrap, Tailwind CSS
  • Version Control - Git and GitHub
  • Responsive Design - Media queries and flexible layouts
  • Web Accessibility - Making sites usable for everyone

Practice Project Ideas

  • Personal portfolio website
  • Restaurant menu page
  • Product landing page
  • Blog layout
  • Photo gallery

Resources for Learning More

  • MDN Web Docs - The ultimate reference
  • W3Schools - Interactive tutorials
  • CSS-Tricks - Advanced CSS techniques
  • Frontend Mentor - Real-world projects

Remember This

Web development is a journey, not a destination. Start simple, practice regularly, and don't be afraid to experiment.

The web development community is incredibly supportive. Don't hesitate to ask questions and share your work!
